conclusion: Relate EMF \( E \) to velocity \( v \) and flow rate \( Q \).
Conductive liquid flows with velocity \( v \) through a magnetic field \( B \) perpendicular to the flow.
EMF is generated between points \( M \) and \( N \) due to Lorentz force.
EMF \( E \) is given by \( E = B \cdot v \cdot d \).
Force per unit charge is \( \mathbf{F} = q(\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{B}) \).
Potential difference (EMF) is work done per unit charge.
Flow rate \( Q \) is volume of liquid per unit time.
Cross-sectional area \( A \) of the pipe is \( A = \frac{\pi d^2}{4} \).
Flow rate \( Q \) is \( Q = A \cdot v = \frac{\pi d^2}{4} \cdot v \).
Substitute \( v \) into flow rate equation: \( Q = \frac{\pi d^2}{4} \cdot \frac{E}{B \cdot d} \).
Final flow rate \( Q \) is \( Q = \frac{\pi d E}{4 B} \).
